title: Jim Dunegan
text:
James William Dunegan (August 6, 1947 – October 20, 2014) was an American <a href="professional%20baseball">professional baseball</a> player. Although he spent much of his early <a href="Minor%20League%20Baseball">minor league</a> career as an <a href="outfielder">outfielder</a> and <a href="first%20baseman">first baseman</a>, he converted to <a href="pitcher">pitcher</a> in and appeared in seven <a href="games%20played">games</a>, all as a <a href="relief%20pitcher">relief pitcher</a>, that season for the <a href="Chicago%20Cubs">Chicago Cubs</a> of <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a>. He threw and batted right-handed, stood tall and weighed .
Dunegan was selected by Chicago in the second round of the <a href="1967%20Major%20League%20Baseball%20draft">1967 Major League Baseball draft</a>. He hit a career-high 18 <a href="home%20runs">home runs</a> in 1968 for the Class A <a href="Quincy%20Cubs">Quincy Cubs</a> of the <a href="Midwest%20League">Midwest League</a>. After appearing as a pitcher in 14 total games during 1967–1968, and none in 1969, he became a full-time hurler in 1970, splitting the year between the MLB Cubs and their two top <a href="farm%20system">farm system</a> affiliates.
In his debut as a pitcher, on May 30, he entered a game against the <a href="San%20Diego%20Padres">San Diego Padres</a> with the Cubs trailing, 4–0, and worked four <a href="inning%20%28baseball%29">innings</a> of one-<a href="run%20%28baseball%29">run</a> relief, enabling Chicago to climb back into a 4–4 tie. But the Padres broke through for one run off Dunegan to take a 5–4 lead, eventually pinning Dunegan with the loss. He also lost his only other Major League <a href="decision%20%28baseball%29">decision</a>, in June — and also against the Padres. Altogether, he pitched in innings, allowed 13 <a href="hit%20%28baseball%29">hits</a> and 12 <a href="bases%20on%20balls">bases on balls</a>, with three <a href="strikeouts">strikeouts</a>. He left baseball after the 1972 season with a 16–19 <a href="Win%E2%80%93loss%20record%20%28pitching%29">pitching record</a>, an <a href="earned%20run%20average">earned run average</a> of 4.44, a .246 <a href="batting%20average%20%28baseball%29">batting average</a> and 37 <a href="home%20run">home run</a>s as a minor leaguer.
